properties.name: applicationName
properties.description: Gets the application name of the document.

properties.name: author
properties.description: Specifies the author of the document.

properties.name: category
properties.description: Specifies the category of the document.

properties.name: comments
properties.description: Specifies the Comments field in the metadata of the document. These have no connection to comments by users made in the document.

properties.name: company
properties.description: Specifies the company of the document.

properties.name: context
properties.description: The request context associated with the object. This connects the add-in's process to the Office host application's process.

properties.name: creationDate
properties.description: Gets the creation date of the document.

properties.name: customProperties
properties.description: Gets the collection of custom properties of the document.

properties.name: format
properties.description: Specifies the format of the document.

properties.name: keywords
properties.description: Specifies the keywords of the document.

properties.name: lastAuthor
properties.description: Gets the last author of the document.

properties.name: lastPrintDate
properties.description: Gets the last print date of the document.

properties.name: lastSaveTime
properties.description: Gets the last save time of the document.

properties.name: manager
properties.description: Specifies the manager of the document.

properties.name: revisionNumber
properties.description: Gets the revision number of the document.

properties.name: security
properties.description: Gets security settings of the document. Some are access restrictions on the file on disk. Others are Document Protection settings. Some possible values are 0 = File on disk is read/write; 1 = Protect Document: File is encrypted and requires a password to open; 2 = Protect Document: Always Open as Read-Only; 3 = Protect Document: Both #1 and #2; 4 = File on disk is read-only; 5 = Both #1 and #4; 6 = Both #2 and #4; 7 = All of #1, #2, and #4; 8 = Protect Document: Restrict Edit to read-only; 9 = Both #1 and #8; 10 = Both #2 and #8; 11 = All of #1, #2, and #8; 12 = Both #4 and #8; 13 = All of #1, #4, and #8; 14 = All of #2, #4, and #8; 15 = All of #1, #2, #4, and #8.

properties.name: subject
properties.description: Specifies the subject of the document.

properties.name: template
properties.description: Gets the template of the document.

properties.name: title
properties.description: Specifies the title of the document.

methods.name: load
methods.description: Queues up a command to load the specified properties of the object. You must call `context.sync()` before reading the properties.

params.name: options
params.description: Provides options for which properties of the object to load.

params.name: propertyNames
params.description: A comma-delimited string or an array of strings that specify the properties to load.

params.name: propertyNamesAndPaths
params.description: `propertyNamesAndPaths.select` is a comma-delimited string that specifies the properties to load, and `propertyNamesAndPaths.expand` is a comma-delimited string that specifies the navigation properties to load.

methods.name: set
methods.description: Sets multiple properties of an object at the same time. You can pass either a plain object with the appropriate properties, or another API object of the same type.

params.name: properties
params.description: A JavaScript object with properties that are structured isomorphically to the properties of the object on which the method is called.

params.name: options
params.description: Provides an option to suppress errors if the properties object tries to set any read-only properties.

methods.name: toJSON
methods.description: Overrides the JavaScript `toJSON()` method in order to provide more useful output when an API object is passed to `JSON.stringify()`. (`JSON.stringify`, in turn, calls the `toJSON` method of the object that's passed to it.) Whereas the original `Word.DocumentProperties` object is an API object, the `toJSON` method returns a plain JavaScript object (typed as `Word.Interfaces.DocumentPropertiesData`) that contains shallow copies of any loaded child properties from the original object.

methods.name: track
methods.description: Track the object for automatic adjustment based on surrounding changes in the document. This call is a shorthand for [context.trackedObjects.add(thisObject)](/en-us/javascript/api/office/officeextension.clientrequestcontext#office-officeextension-clientrequestcontext-trackedobjects-member). If you're using this object across `.sync` calls and outside the sequential execution of a ".run" batch, and get an "InvalidObjectPath" error when setting a property or invoking a method on the object, you need to add the object to the tracked object collection when the object was first created. If this object is part of a collection, you should also track the parent collection.

methods.name: untrack
methods.description: Release the memory associated with this object, if it has previously been tracked. This call is shorthand for [context.trackedObjects.remove(thisObject)](/en-us/javascript/api/office/officeextension.clientrequestcontext#office-officeextension-clientrequestcontext-trackedobjects-member). Having many tracked objects slows down the host application, so please remember to free any objects you add, once you're done using them. You'll need to call `context.sync()` before the memory release takes effect.
